dictionary.definition: significant good fortune or opportunity.  I need a lucky break about now. She’s never had a lucky break. Mary is going to get a big break soon.
significant good fortune or opportunity.  I need a lucky break about now. She’s never had a lucky break. Mary is going to get a big break soon.
a series of lucky wins in gambling or games. (*Typically: be on ~; have ~.) _ Thanks to a lucky streak, I won enough in Las Vegas to pay for the trip.
a series of lucky wins in gambling or games. (*Typically: be on ~; have ~.) _ Thanks to a lucky streak, I won enough in Las Vegas to pay for the trip.

a quiet period just before a period of great activity or excitement. (Literal in reference to weather.) _ It was very quiet in the cafeteria just before the students came in for lunch. It was the lull before the storm.  In the brief calm before the storm, the clerks prepared themselves for the doors to open and bring in thousands of shoppers.

dictionary.phrase: lump someone and someone else together
dictionary.definition: to classify people or things as members of the same category. You just can’t lump Bill and Ted together. They are totally different kinds of people.  I tend to lump apples and oranges together.

dictionary.phrase: lump something and something else together
dictionary.definition: to classify people or things as members of the same category. You just can’t lump Bill and Ted together. They are totally different kinds of people.  I tend to lump apples and oranges together.
to sway or turn quickly toward someone or something. Todd lurched at the door and got it open just as the guard saw him.  Bill lurched toward the ship’s rail and hung on.
to sway or turn quickly toward someone or something. Todd lurched at the door and got it open just as the guard saw him.  Bill lurched toward the ship’s rail and hung on.

dictionary.phrase: lure someone or something in to something
dictionary.definition: to entice someone or something into something or a place.  The thief tried to lure the tourist into an alley to rob him. Using an old trick, the thief lured in the tourist.
to entice someone or something into something or a place.  The thief tried to lure the tourist into an alley to rob him. Using an old trick, the thief lured in the tourist.
to desire someone sexually.  You could see that Sam was lusting after Sally.  Roger claims that he does not lust for anyone.
to desire someone sexually.  You could see that Sam was lusting after Sally.  Roger claims that he does not lust for anyone.

1. crazy. (Alludes to the crazy characters in Lewis Carroll’s Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland. *Also: as ~.) _Poor old John is as mad as a hatter.  All these screaming children are driving me mad as a hatter. 2. angry. (This is a misunderstanding of mad in the first sense. *Also: as ~.) _ You make me so angry! I’m as mad as a hatter. John can’t control his temper. He’s always mad as a hatter.

very angry. (*Also: as ~. Use hell with caution.) _ You make me so angry. I’m as mad as a hornet. What you said made Mary mad as a wet hen. Those terrorists make me mad as hell.

dictionary.phrase: mad enough to chew nails (and spit rivets)
dictionary.definition: Inf. Fig. very angry, as if to be able to bite through metal nails.  I am mad enough to chew nails! Who took my checkbook? _ Her sudden tirade made him angry enough to chew nails.  He stomped in, mad enough to chew nails and spit rivets.

Inf. Fig. very angry, as if to be able to bite through metal nails.  I am mad enough to chew nails! Who took my checkbook? _ Her sudden tirade made him angry enough to chew nails.  He stomped in, mad enough to chew nails and spit rivets.

dictionary.phrase: make a (big) stink (about someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to make trouble about someone or something. Why did you raise a big stink about it? _Jim is making a stink about Alice.

dictionary.phrase: raise a (big) stink (about someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to make trouble about someone or something. Why did you raise a big stink about it? _Jim is making a stink about Alice.
to make a lot of money. John really made a bundle on that deal. I’d like to make a pile and retire.
to make a lot of money. John really made a bundle on that deal. I’d like to make a pile and retire.

dictionary.phrase: make a day of doing something
dictionary.definition: to spend the whole day doing something.  We went to the museum to see the new exhibit and then decided to make a day of it.  They made a day of cleaning the attic.
to spend the whole day doing something.  We went to the museum to see the new exhibit and then decided to make a day of it.  They made a day of cleaning the attic.

1. to show a funny or distorted expression to someone in ridicule.  Mother, Billy made a face at me! _ The teacher sent Jane to the principal for making a face in class. 2. to attempt to communicate to someone through facial gestures, usually an attempt to say “no” or “stop.” _ I started to tell John where I was last night, but Bill made a face so I didn’t.  John made a face at me as I was testifying, so I avoided telling everything.

John made a face at me as I was testifying, so I avoided telling everything.
to make money with little effort or in a short time. Tom is always ready to make a fast buck.  I made a quick buck selling used cars.

dictionary.phrase: make a federal case out of something
dictionary.definition: to exaggerate the seriousness of something.  Come on. It was nothing! Don’t make a federal case out of it. I only stepped on your toe. Don’t make a big deal about it.

dictionary.phrase: make a big deal about something
dictionary.definition: to exaggerate the seriousness of something.  Come on. It was nothing! Don’t make a federal case out of it. I only stepped on your toe. Don’t make a big deal about it.
to make someone look foolish.  John made a monkey out of himself while trying to make a fool out of Jim.  John made a fool out of himself at the party.  Are you trying to make a monkey out of me?
to make someone look foolish.  John made a monkey out of himself while trying to make a fool out of Jim.  John made a fool out of himself at the party.  Are you trying to make a monkey out of me?
to establish a link of friendship with someone. I have never found it difficult to make friends. Mary had to make new friends when she changed schools.
to establish a link of friendship with someone. I have never found it difficult to make friends. Mary had to make new friends when she changed schools.

dictionary.phrase: make a laughingstock of oneself or something
dictionary.definition: to make oneself a source of ridicule or laughter; to do something that invites ridicule. Laura made herself a laughingstock by arriving at the fast-food restaurant in full evening dress.  The board of directors made the company a laughingstock by hiring an ex-convict as president.

dictionary.phrase: make oneself or something a laughingstock
dictionary.definition: to make oneself a source of ridicule or laughter; to do something that invites ridicule. Laura made herself a laughingstock by arriving at the fast-food restaurant in full evening dress.  The board of directors made the company a laughingstock by hiring an ex-convict as president.
to earn a living from something or by doing something.  John makes a living from painting houses.  Can you really make a living by selling jewelry?

dictionary.phrase: make a living by doing something
dictionary.definition: to earn a living from something or by doing something.  John makes a living from painting houses.  Can you really make a living by selling jewelry?

to leave out parts of a story to make it shorter; to bring a story to an end. (A formula that introduces a summary of a story or a joke. See also long story short.) _ And— to make a long story short—I never got back the money that I lent him. If I can make a long story short, let me say that everything worked out fine.

to score a point in a game.  Bob made a point in the last match.  Karen made twenty points in the second half.

dictionary.phrase: make a point of doing something
dictionary.definition: to make an effort to do something. Please make a point of mailing this letter. It’s very important.  The hostess made a point of thanking me for bringing flowers.
to make an effort to do something. Please make a point of mailing this letter. It’s very important.  The hostess made a point of thanking me for bringing flowers.

dictionary.phrase: make a point of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to turn someone or something into an important matter. Please don’t make a point of John’s comment. It wasn’t that important.  I hope you make an issue of Tom’s success and the reasons for it.

dictionary.phrase: make an issue of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to turn someone or something into an important matter. Please don’t make a point of John’s comment. It wasn’t that important.  I hope you make an issue of Tom’s success and the reasons for it.
to turn something into a habitual activity.  Jane makes a practice of planting daisies every summer.  Her mother also made it a practice.
to turn something into a habitual activity.  Jane makes a practice of planting daisies every summer.  Her mother also made it a practice.

to reserve a seat, as in an airplane, restaurant, or theater in advance; to reserve a room, as in a hotel in advance.  Did you make a reservation or are we just going to chance getting a table? _ I made reservations for a f light at twelve noon.

to make a public display or disturbance.  When John found a f ly in his drink, he started to create a scene.  Oh, John, please don’t make a scene. Just forget about it.

to flirt with someone; to begin to seduce someone.  She began making advances to me, and I left the room.  Mary made advances at every male she encountered.

dictionary.phrase: make away with someone or something
dictionary.definition: to take someone or something away; to make someone or something disappear.  The robber made away with the jewelry.  The maid quickly made off with the children. We only saw them for a moment.

dictionary.phrase: make off with someone or something
dictionary.definition: to take someone or something away; to make someone or something disappear.  The robber made away with the jewelry.  The maid quickly made off with the children. We only saw them for a moment.

dictionary.phrase: make demands of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to expect someone or something to do something or act in a particular way.  Please don’t make demands of everyone in the shop.  The boss is making a lot of demands on the new machinery.

dictionary.phrase: make demands on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to expect someone or something to do something or act in a particular way.  Please don’t make demands of everyone in the shop.  The boss is making a lot of demands on the new machinery.

Prov. Act quickly, but not so quickly that you make careless mistakes.  Jane: Why are you throwing your clothes around the room? Alan: You told me to get my things packed in a hurry. Jane: Yes, but make haste slowly; otherwise we’ll have to spend an hour cleaning up the mess you make.  I know you want to finish that sweater by Joe’s birthday, but you’re knitting so fast that you make mistakes. More haste, less speed.

dictionary.phrase: make it one’s business to do something
dictionary.definition: to do something on one’s own even if it means interfering in something that does not directly concern one. (As opposed to minding one’s own business.) _ I know it doesn’t concern me, but I made it my business to call city hall because someone had to.  Jane took it upon herself to find out exactly what had happened to the old lady.

dictionary.phrase: take it upon oneself to do something
dictionary.definition: to do something on one’s own even if it means interfering in something that does not directly concern one. (As opposed to minding one’s own business.) _ I know it doesn’t concern me, but I made it my business to call city hall because someone had to.  Jane took it upon herself to find out exactly what had happened to the old lady.

to beat or pound someone or something; to treat someone or something roughly. (As if chopping someone up.) _ If you don’t behave, I’ll make mincemeat out of you.  Do you want Fred to make hamburger out of you?

dictionary.phrase: make short work of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to finish with someone or something quickly.  I made short work of Tom so I could leave the office to play golf.  Billy made fast work of his dinner so he could go out and play.

dictionary.phrase: make fast work of someone or something

to cause someone’s skin to feel funny or get goose pimples through fright.  Just to hear the story of the killings made my f lesh crawl. The horror movie made our skin crawl.

1. Fig. to make someone dizzy or disoriented. Riding the merry-go-round makes my head spin.  Breathing the gas made my head swim. 2. Fig. to confuse or overwhelm someone. All these numbers make my head swim.  The physics lecture made my head spin.

to restore a bed to an unslept-in condition. I make my bed every morning.  The maid goes to all the rooms to make the beds.  Please make up all the beds early today.

to cause a fight or an argument; to create an uproar.  When your mother gets home and sees what you’ve done, she’ll really make the fur f ly. When those two get together, they’ll make the feathers f ly. They hate each other.

dictionary.phrase: Many a true word is spoken in jest.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Just because something is said as a joke, it can still be true. Fred: Why did you make a joke about my being stingy? Do you really think I’m cheap? Ellen: Of course not, don’t be silly. It was just a joke. Fred: But many a true word is spoken in jest.

dictionary.phrase: There’s many a true word spoken in jest.
dictionary.definition: Prov. Just because something is said as a joke, it can still be true. Fred: Why did you make a joke about my being stingy? Do you really think I’m cheap? Ellen: Of course not, don’t be silly. It was just a joke. Fred: But many a true word is spoken in jest.

dictionary.phrase: March comes in like a lion, and goes out like a lamb.
dictionary.definition: Prov. The month of March usually starts with cold, unpleasant weather, but ends mild and pleasant. (Either part of the proverb can be used alone.) _ March certainly is coming in like a lion this year; there’s been a snowstorm every day this week. Jill: Today is March twenty-fifth, and it’s beautiful and warm outside, when just two weeks ago, everything was covered with ice. Jane: In like a lion and out like a lamb, all right.

dictionary.phrase: In like a lion, out like a lamb.
dictionary.definition: Prov. The month of March usually starts with cold, unpleasant weather, but ends mild and pleasant. (Either part of the proverb can be used alone.) _ March certainly is coming in like a lion this year; there’s been a snowstorm every day this week. Jill: Today is March twenty-fifth, and it’s beautiful and warm outside, when just two weeks ago, everything was covered with ice. Jane: In like a lion and out like a lamb, all right.
to cross off the name of someone or something. They were late, so I marked them off. I marked off the late people. Could you mark that title out? It has been discontinued.
to cross off the name of someone or something. They were late, so I marked them off. I marked off the late people. Could you mark that title out? It has been discontinued.
a happy or harmonious marriage or partnership.  The partnership of George and Ira Gershwin was a match made in heaven; they wrote such beautiful songs.
a happy or harmonious marriage or partnership.  The partnership of George and Ira Gershwin was a match made in heaven; they wrote such beautiful songs.
to marry someone in a lower social class than oneself.  He married beneath himself, but he is happy, and what more is required of a marriage? _ He did not want to marry beneath himself.
to marry someone in a lower social class than oneself.  He married beneath himself, but he is happy, and what more is required of a marriage? _ He did not want to marry beneath himself.
to pair people or things.  I will match Carl up with Kelly and George with Jane.  I will match up Carl with Kelly.
to pair people or things.  I will match Carl up with Kelly and George with Jane.  I will match up Carl with Kelly.
to pair or breed people or animals.  The king sought to mate his daughter with the son of a magician.  Harry wanted to mate his guppies with June’s guppies.

dictionary.phrase: mate an animal with some other animal
dictionary.definition: to pair or breed people or animals.  The king sought to mate his daughter with the son of a magician.  Harry wanted to mate his guppies with June’s guppies.

a polite phrase said by a person whose invitation has just been turned down by another person.  Bill: Do you think you can come to the party? Bob: I’ll have to beg off. I have another engagement. Bill: Maybe some other time.  John: Can you and Alice come over this Friday? Bill: Gee, sorry. We have something else on. John: We’ll try again some other time.

dictionary.phrase: We’ll try again some other time.
dictionary.definition: a polite phrase said by a person whose invitation has just been turned down by another person.  Bill: Do you think you can come to the party? Bob: I’ll have to beg off. I have another engagement. Bill: Maybe some other time.  John: Can you and Alice come over this Friday? Bill: Gee, sorry. We have something else on. John: We’ll try again some other time.
to die. After 20 years, my dog finally met his death when he got hit by a bus.  The skydiver met his end when his parachute didn’t open.
to die. After 20 years, my dog finally met his death when he got hit by a bus.  The skydiver met his end when his parachute didn’t open.

dictionary.phrase: merge someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to route someone or something into something else.  They merged the marchers into the parade and no one ever knew they were late. We merged in the latecomers to the parade at an intersection.
to route someone or something into something else.  They merged the marchers into the parade and no one ever knew they were late. We merged in the latecomers to the parade at an intersection.
very happy and carefree. (*Also: as ~.) _ Mary is as merry as a cricket whenever she has company come to call.  The little children are as merry as the day is long.

1. to waste time; to do something ineffectually.  Stop messing around and get busy. I wish you wouldn’t mess about so much. You waste a lot of time that way. 2. to play [with someone] sexually.  Those two have been messing around.  Pete was messing around with Maria during the summer.

1. to waste time; to do something ineffectually.  Stop messing around and get busy. I wish you wouldn’t mess about so much. You waste a lot of time that way. 2. to play [with someone] sexually.  Those two have been messing around.  Pete was messing around with Maria during the summer.

1. to play with or fiddle with something idly and with no good purpose.  Don’t mess around with the ashtray.  You’ll break it if you don’t stop messing about with it. 2. to experiment with something; to use and learn about something.  We had been messing about with some new video techniques when we made our discovery.  The people in this lab are messing around with all kinds of polymers.

to bother or interfere with someone or something.  Come on, don’t monkey with my new camera.  Don’t mess with me unless you want trouble.

a phrase indicating that it is probably better to do something than not to do it.  Bill: Should we try to get there for the first showing of the film? Jane: Might as well. Nothing else to do.  Andy: May as well leave now. It doesn’t matter if we arrive a little bit early. Jane: Why do we always have to be the first to arrive?

a very important event or point in one’s life. (From the [former] stone markers at the side of a road showing the distance to or from a place.) _ Joan’s wedding was a milestone in her mother’s life.  The birth of a child is a milestone in every parent’s life.

dictionary.phrase: an important milestone in someone’s life
dictionary.definition: a very important event or point in one’s life. (From the [former] stone markers at the side of a road showing the distance to or from a place.) _ Joan’s wedding was a milestone in her mother’s life.  The birth of a child is a milestone in every parent’s life.
to wander or move around aimlessly within a small area.  Everyone was milling around, looking for something to do. The students milled about between classes.
to wander or move around aimlessly within a small area.  Everyone was milling around, looking for something to do. The students milled about between classes.
to take care of local matters.  Please stay here in the office and mind the store while I go to the conference.  I had to stay home and watch the store when Ann went to Boston.

Stop prying into my affairs. (Not at all polite. The expressions with get and keep can have the literal meanings of removing and keeping removed.) _ Andy: This is none of your affair. Mind your own business. Sue: I was only trying to help.  Bob: How much did you pay in federal taxes last year? Jane: Good grief, Bob! Keep your nose out of my business! _Tom: How much did it cost? Sue: Tom! Get your nose out of my business! _ “Hey!” shrieked Sally, jerking the checkbook out of Sue’s grasp. “Get your nose out of my business!”

to mix people together; to mix things together.  Try to mingle your friends with mine.  You had better not mingle your money with that of the corporation.
to fail to participate in something; to fail to take part in something.  I’m sorry I missed out on the ice cream.  I lost out on getting in the class photo because I was sick that day.
to fail to participate in something; to fail to take part in something.  I’m sorry I missed out on the ice cream.  I lost out on getting in the class photo because I was sick that day.
[for glass] to fog up; [for glass] to develop a coating of water vapor so that one cannot see.  The windshield misted over and we could hardly see out.  The glass misted up and we had to wipe it off.

to confuse someone with someone else; to think that one person is another person.  I’m sorry. I mistook you for John.  Tom is always mistaking Bill for me. We don’t look a thing alike, though.  Try not to mix Bill up with Bob, his twin.

dictionary.phrase: mix someone up with someone else
dictionary.definition: to confuse someone with someone else; to think that one person is another person.  I’m sorry. I mistook you for John.  Tom is always mistaking Bill for me. We don’t look a thing alike, though.  Try not to mix Bill up with Bob, his twin.
to confuse two things with each other.  Please don’t mix this idea up with that one.  I mistook my book for yours.

dictionary.phrase: mix something up with something else
dictionary.definition: to confuse two things with each other.  Please don’t mix this idea up with that one.  I mistook my book for yours.

dictionary.phrase: mix someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to combine someone or something into something.  We will try to mix the new people into the group.  We will mix in the new people a few at a time.
to combine someone or something into something.  We will try to mix the new people into the group.  We will mix in the new people a few at a time.
to use something as a pattern for something; to use someone as a pattern for someone.  I will model my house on the house we saw in the Mediterranean.  She tried to model herself on her mother.
to use something as a pattern for something; to use someone as a pattern for someone.  I will model my house on the house we saw in the Mediterranean.  She tried to model herself on her mother.
to form something, using a pliable substance, such as clay, plastic, wet concrete, etc.  She molded a small turtle out of the moist clay. Elaine molded a turtle from the clay.

It does not matter how much something costs.  Please show me your finest automobile. Money is no object.  I want the finest earrings you have. Don’t worry about how much they cost because expense is no object.

It does not matter how much something costs.  Please show me your finest automobile. Money is no object.  I want the finest earrings you have. Don’t worry about how much they cost because expense is no object.

dictionary.phrase: Money is the root of all evil.
dictionary.definition: Prov. People do many evil things in order to get rich. (Biblical. Compare this with Idleness is the root of all evil.) _ Fred: I know I could make more money if I just knew the right things to invest in. Ellen: Don’t worry so much about money. It’s the root of all evil, after all.  As the newspapers continued to report the dastardly things the wealthy young banker had done to become even wealthier, people shook their heads and remarked, “The love of money is the root of all evil.”

dictionary.phrase: The love of money is the root of all evil.
dictionary.definition: Prov. People do many evil things in order to get rich. (Biblical. Compare this with Idleness is the root of all evil.) _ Fred: I know I could make more money if I just knew the right things to invest in. Ellen: Don’t worry so much about money. It’s the root of all evil, after all.  As the newspapers continued to report the dastardly things the wealthy young banker had done to become even wealthier, people shook their heads and remarked, “The love of money is the root of all evil.”
silliness; dishonest tricks. That’s enough monkey business. Now, settle down.  Stop the funny business. This is serious!
silliness; dishonest tricks. That’s enough monkey business. Now, settle down.  Stop the funny business. This is serious!
to pine or grieve about someone or something.  Stop mooning about your cat. Cats always come back eventually.  Jill is still mooning over Robert.
to pine or grieve about someone or something.  Stop mooning about your cat. Cats always come back eventually.  Jill is still mooning over Robert.

dictionary.phrase: more fun than a barrel of monkeys
dictionary.definition: Cliché a great deal of fun. (Compare this with as funny as a barrel of monkeys.) _ Roger always makes me laugh! He is as much fun as a barrel of monkeys.  The circus was more fun than a barrel of monkeys.

dictionary.phrase: as much fun as a barrel of monkeys
dictionary.definition: Cliché a great deal of fun. (Compare this with as funny as a barrel of monkeys.) _ Roger always makes me laugh! He is as much fun as a barrel of monkeys.  The circus was more fun than a barrel of monkeys.
more of something, such as trouble or something bad, than a person can endure.  This tragic news is more than I can bear! _ I’ve heard enough of this horrid music. It’s more than I can stand.
more of something, such as trouble or something bad, than a person can endure.  This tragic news is more than I can bear! _ I’ve heard enough of this horrid music. It’s more than I can stand.
more of something, such as trouble or something bad, than a person can endure.  This tragic news is more than I can bear! _ I’ve heard enough of this horrid music. It’s more than I can stand.

dictionary.phrase: The more you get, the more you want.
dictionary.definition: Prov. People are never satisfied with what they have.  You may think that you’ll be content being department supervisor, but power is like anything else—the more you have, the more you want.

dictionary.phrase: The more you have, the more you want.
dictionary.definition: Prov. People are never satisfied with what they have.  You may think that you’ll be content being department supervisor, but power is like anything else—the more you have, the more you want.

to give someone a hand signal to move to the side of something, such as the road. (Very similar to motion someone aside.) _ The cop motioned her to the side of the road.  Claire motioned Fred to one side, where she spoke to him.

to give someone a hand signal to move to the side of something, such as the road. (Very similar to motion someone aside.) _ The cop motioned her to the side of the road.  Claire motioned Fred to one side, where she spoke to him.
to grieve for someone or something.  Everyone will mourn for you when you go.  We all mourned over the end of the holiday.  There is no point in mourning over your cat. It won’t come back.
to grieve for someone or something.  Everyone will mourn for you when you go.  We all mourned over the end of the holiday.  There is no point in mourning over your cat. It won’t come back.
to move here and there a bit; to stir; to walk around a bit.  Stay where you are. Don’t move around at all! _ I wish you would stop moving about.
to move here and there a bit; to stir; to walk around a bit.  Stay where you are. Don’t move around at all! _ I wish you would stop moving about.

dictionary.phrase: move someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to cause someone or something to enter something or some place.  We moved Carla into the spare room.  We found a vacant room and moved in the piano.
to cause someone or something to enter something or some place.  We moved Carla into the spare room.  We found a vacant room and moved in the piano.
to advance (oneself ) and become successful. The harder I work, the more I move up in the world.  Keep your eye on John. He’s really coming up in the world.
to advance (oneself ) and become successful. The harder I work, the more I move up in the world.  Keep your eye on John. He’s really coming up in the world.
to force someone out of something; to push someone out of something. (Can be physical or by coercion.) _Are you trying to muscle me out of my job? _The younger people are muscling out the older ones.
to force someone out of something; to push someone out of something. (Can be physical or by coercion.) _Are you trying to muscle me out of my job? _The younger people are muscling out the older ones.

a polite expression said to make a guest feel at home. (From the Spanish phrase Mi casa, su casa.) _ Bill: Hello, Tom. Tom (entering): So nice you can put me up for the night. Bill: My house is your house, make yourself at home. Mary: Come in, you two. Bill: Thanks. Sue: Yes, thank you. Mary: Well, what can I get you? My house is your house.

a polite expression said to make a guest feel at home. (From the Spanish phrase Mi casa, su casa.) _ Bill: Hello, Tom. Tom (entering): So nice you can put me up for the night. Bill: My house is your house, make yourself at home. Mary: Come in, you two. Bill: Thanks. Sue: Yes, thank you. Mary: Well, what can I get you? My house is your house.

to punish or scold someone severely. (Literally, to crucify someone or to nail someone’s skin to the wall like that of a captured animal.) _That guy was really mad. He really nailed you to a cross.  She must hate your guts. She sure nailed your hide to the wall.

dictionary.phrase: nail someone (‘s hide) to the wall
dictionary.definition: to punish or scold someone severely. (Literally, to crucify someone or to nail someone’s skin to the wall like that of a captured animal.) _That guy was really mad. He really nailed you to a cross.  She must hate your guts. She sure nailed your hide to the wall.
to attach something onto something by nailing.  Suzy nailed the hose bracket onto the side of the house.  She nailed on the bracket.  Laura nailed the bracket to the wall.
to attach something onto something by nailing.  Suzy nailed the hose bracket onto the side of the house.  She nailed on the bracket.  Laura nailed the bracket to the wall.
to attach something onto something by nailing.  Suzy nailed the hose bracket onto the side of the house.  She nailed on the bracket.  Laura nailed the bracket to the wall.
to give someone (usually a baby) the name of another person.  We named our baby after my aunt.  My parents named me for my grandfather.
to give someone (usually a baby) the name of another person.  We named our baby after my aunt.  My parents named me for my grandfather.

a phrase that introduces a reminder. (A little haughty or parental.) _ Bill: Need I remind you that today is Friday? Bob (sarcastically): Gee, how else would I have known? _ John: Need I remind you of our policy against smoking in the office? Jane: Sorry, I forgot.

dictionary.phrase: negotiate (with someone or something) (over someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to bargain with someone or a group about someone or something. We decided to negotiate with them over the terms of the contract.  We want to negotiate with them about the cost of the goods.  They refused to negotiate with our purchasing agent.

dictionary.phrase: negotiate (with someone or something) (about someone or something)

to lie close to someone or something; to cuddle up to someone or something.  The kitten nestled up against its mother.  The shivering puppy nestled up to Kathy.
to lie close to someone or something; to cuddle up to someone or something.  The kitten nestled up against its mother.  The shivering puppy nestled up to Kathy.

Prov. Someone who is new in a particular job will do a very good job at first, to prove how competent he or she is.  Jill: That new supervisor is awfully strict. Jane: New brooms sweep clean.  The new teacher immediately f lunked three of the laziest students. “A new broom sweeps clean,” one of the students shrugged.

1. Inf. That was done well.  John: Well, I’m glad that’s over. Sally: Nice going, John! You did a good job.  Tom: Nice job, Bill! Bill: Thanks, Tom! 2. Fig. That was done poorly. (Sarcastic.) _ Fred: I guess I really messed it up. Bill: Nice job, Fred! You’ve now messed us all up! Fred: Well, I’m sorry.  “Nice going,” frowned Jane, as Tom upset the bowl of potato chips.

to clip or cut something off something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ Let me nip a few blossoms off the rosebush.  I nipped off a few blossoms and made a bouquet.
to clip or cut something off something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ Let me nip a few blossoms off the rosebush.  I nipped off a few blossoms and made a bouquet.
Inf. [of something] not difficult or troublesome. Don’t worry. It’s no big deal to wash the car.  No problem. It’s no biggie.
Inf. [of something] not difficult or troublesome. Don’t worry. It’s no big deal to wash the car.  No problem. It’s no biggie.
no anger or resentment. I hope you don’t have any hard feelings.  No, I have no hard feelings.
no anger or resentment. I hope you don’t have any hard feelings.  No, I have no hard feelings.

dictionary.phrase: no ifs, ands, or buts (about it)
dictionary.definition: absolutely no discussion, dissension, or doubt about something. I want you there exactly at eight, no ifs, ands, or buts about it.  This is the best television set available for the money, no buts about it.

absolutely no discussion, dissension, or doubt about something. I want you there exactly at eight, no ifs, ands, or buts about it.  This is the best television set available for the money, no buts about it.
no difficulty for someone; no cause for concern to someone.  It’s no skin off my nose if she wants to act that way. She said it was no skin off her teeth if we wanted to sell the house.
no difficulty for someone; no cause for concern to someone.  It’s no skin off my nose if she wants to act that way. She said it was no skin off her teeth if we wanted to sell the house.
Inf. no difficulty; do not worry.  Of course I can have your car repaired by noon. No sweat.  You’d like a red one? No problem.
Inf. no difficulty; do not worry.  Of course I can have your car repaired by noon. No sweat.  You’d like a red one? No problem.
a phrase used to decline something.  Bob: Would you care for some more coffee? Mary: No, thank you. John: Do you want to go downtown tonight? Jane: No, thanks.
a phrase used to decline something.  Bob: Would you care for some more coffee? Mary: No, thank you. John: Do you want to go downtown tonight? Jane: No, thanks.

to spread around a secret; to gossip something around.  Now don’t noise it about, but I am going to Houston next week to see my girl.  Please don’t noise this abroad.  Stop noising that gossip around.

to spread around a secret; to gossip something around.  Now don’t noise it about, but I am going to Houston next week to see my girl.  Please don’t noise this abroad.  Stop noising that gossip around.

to search here and there to find someone or something. We spent an hour nosing about for a newspaper.  I will nose around for someone to help you.  We nosed about for a while, but found no one.
to search here and there to find someone or something. We spent an hour nosing about for a newspaper.  I will nose around for someone to help you.  We nosed about for a while, but found no one.

[for an animal] to force something out of something gently and cautiously. (As if pushing with the nose.) _ The cat nosed her kitten out of the corner.  The cat nosed out her kittens where we could see them. She nosed them out.

no idea.  A: Where’s the subway? B: Sorry. Not a glimmer of an idea.  How long till we’re there? Not a clue.
no idea.  A: Where’s the subway? B: Sorry. Not a glimmer of an idea.  How long till we’re there? Not a clue.
just in time; with no extra time.  Hurry, hurry! There’s not a moment to spare! _ I arrived without a moment to spare.
just in time; with no extra time.  Hurry, hurry! There’s not a moment to spare! _ I arrived without a moment to spare.

dictionary.phrase: not able to stomach someone or something
dictionary.definition: not to be able to put up with someone or something; not to be able to tolerate or endure someone or something.  Jane cannot stomach violent movies.  The sensitive student could not stomach a lot of ridicule.

not to be able to put up with someone or something; not to be able to tolerate or endure someone or something.  Jane cannot stomach violent movies.  The sensitive student could not stomach a lot of ridicule.

dictionary.phrase: not all something is cracked up to be
dictionary.definition: not as good as something is said to be. (Not always in the negative.) _ This isn’t a very good pen. It’s not all it’s cracked up to be.  Is this one all it’s cracked up to be?

dictionary.phrase: not what something is cracked up to be
dictionary.definition: not as good as something is said to be. (Not always in the negative.) _ This isn’t a very good pen. It’s not all it’s cracked up to be.  Is this one all it’s cracked up to be?
certainly not; absolutely not. No, it doesn’t bother me—not at all. I’m not complaining. Not me. Not in the least.
certainly not; absolutely not. No, it doesn’t bother me—not at all. I’m not complaining. Not me. Not in the least.

to show no signs of distress even when something bad happens or something shocking is said.  Sam didn’t bat an eyelid when the mechanic told him how much the car repairs would cost.  The pain of the broken arm must have hurt Sally terribly, but she did not bat an eyelid.

dictionary.phrase: not breathe a word (about someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to keep a secret about someone or something.  Don’t worry. I won’t breathe a word about this matter. Please don’t breathe a word about Bob and his problems. Don’t worry. I won’t breathe a word of it.

dictionary.phrase: not breathe a word of it
dictionary.definition: to keep a secret about someone or something.  Don’t worry. I won’t breathe a word about this matter. Please don’t breathe a word about Bob and his problems. Don’t worry. I won’t breathe a word of it.

dictionary.phrase: not care two hoots about someone or something
dictionary.definition: Inf. not to care at all about someone or something.  I don’t care two hoots about whether you go to the picnic or not. She doesn’t give a hoot about me. Why should I care? _ I don’t give a hang about it.

dictionary.phrase: not give two hoots about someone or something
dictionary.definition: Inf. not to care at all about someone or something.  I don’t care two hoots about whether you go to the picnic or not. She doesn’t give a hoot about me. Why should I care? _ I don’t give a hang about it.

dictionary.phrase: not give a hang about someone or something

dictionary.phrase: not give a hoot about someone or something

to feel upset, troubled, or disturbed in some way.  I’m sorry I said what I said. I’m not feeling myself today.
to feel upset, troubled, or disturbed in some way.  I’m sorry I said what I said. I’m not feeling myself today.

not for anything (no matter what its value). (Note the variation in the examples. The order of love nor money is fixed.) _ I won’t do it for love nor money.  He said he wouldn’t do it—not for the world.

not for anything (no matter what its value). (Note the variation in the examples. The order of love nor money is fixed.) _ I won’t do it for love nor money.  He said he wouldn’t do it—not for the world.

not for anything (no matter what its value). (Note the variation in the examples. The order of love nor money is fixed.) _ I won’t do it for love nor money.  He said he wouldn’t do it—not for the world.

dictionary.phrase: not have a snowball’s chance in hell
dictionary.definition: Inf. a very poor chance. (Usually in the negative.) _She doesn’t have a snowball’s chance in hell of getting it done on time.  I know I don’t have a hope in hell, but I’ll try anyway.
Inf. a very poor chance. (Usually in the negative.) _She doesn’t have a snowball’s chance in hell of getting it done on time.  I know I don’t have a hope in hell, but I’ll try anyway.

dictionary.phrase: not hold a stick to someone or something
dictionary.definition: not to be nearly as good as someone or something.  Sally is much faster than Bob. Bob doesn’t hold a stick to Sally.  This TV doesn’t hold a candle to that one. That one is much better.

dictionary.phrase: not hold a candle to someone or something
dictionary.definition: not to be nearly as good as someone or something.  Sally is much faster than Bob. Bob doesn’t hold a stick to Sally.  This TV doesn’t hold a candle to that one. That one is much better.

dictionary.phrase: Not if I see you sooner.
dictionary.definition: Inf. a response to I’ll see you later. (This means you will not see me if I see you first, because I will avoid you.) _ Tom: See you later. Mary: Not if I see you sooner.  John: Okay. If you want to argue, I’ll just leave. See you later. Mary: Not if I see you first.

dictionary.phrase: Not if I see you first.
dictionary.definition: Inf. a response to I’ll see you later. (This means you will not see me if I see you first, because I will avoid you.) _ Tom: See you later. Mary: Not if I see you sooner.  John: Okay. If you want to argue, I’ll just leave. See you later. Mary: Not if I see you first.
No, never! _John: Will you ever approve of her marriage to Tom? Sue: No, not in a thousand years! _Mary: Will all this trouble ever subside? John: Never in a thousand years!

to have no idea about what to do (about something).  I was so confused I didn’t know where to turn.  We needed help, but we didn’t know which way to turn.

dictionary.phrase: not know which way to turn
dictionary.definition: to have no idea about what to do (about something).  I was so confused I didn’t know where to turn.  We needed help, but we didn’t know which way to turn.

dictionary.phrase: not know whether one is coming or going
dictionary.definition: to be very confused.  I’m so busy that I don’t know if I’m coming or going. You look as if you don’t know whether you’re coming or going.

dictionary.phrase: not know if one is coming or going
dictionary.definition: to be very confused.  I’m so busy that I don’t know if I’m coming or going. You look as if you don’t know whether you’re coming or going.

dictionary.phrase: not let someone catch someone doing something
dictionary.definition: an expression that scolds someone who has done something wrong. (The idea is that the person ought not to do the wrong thing again, not that the person simply avoid getting caught.) _ How many times have I told you not to play ball in the house? Don’t let me catch you doing that again.  If I’ve told you once, I’ve told you a thousand times: Don’t do that! I don’t want to catch you doing it again!

dictionary.phrase: not want to catch someone doing something
dictionary.definition: an expression that scolds someone who has done something wrong. (The idea is that the person ought not to do the wrong thing again, not that the person simply avoid getting caught.) _ How many times have I told you not to play ball in the house? Don’t let me catch you doing that again.  If I’ve told you once, I’ve told you a thousand times: Don’t do that! I don’t want to catch you doing it again!

dictionary.phrase: not lift a finger (to help someone)
dictionary.definition: to do nothing to help someone. (The someone is anyone with the negative.) _ They wouldn’t lift a finger to help us.  Can you imagine that they wouldn’t lift a finger? _ Sally refused to lift a hand to help her own sister.

dictionary.phrase: not lift a hand (to help someone)
dictionary.definition: to do nothing to help someone. (The someone is anyone with the negative.) _ They wouldn’t lift a finger to help us.  Can you imagine that they wouldn’t lift a finger? _ Sally refused to lift a hand to help her own sister.

dictionary.phrase: not miss something for the world
dictionary.definition: would not miss something for any reason at all. Of course I’ll be at your wedding. I wouldn’t miss it for the world.

dictionary.phrase: not miss something for love nor money
dictionary.definition: would not miss something for any reason at all. Of course I’ll be at your wedding. I wouldn’t miss it for the world.
not to say anything at all; not to tell something (to anyone).  Don’t worry, I’ll keep your secret. I won’t even open my mouth.  Have no fear. I won’t utter a word.
not to say anything at all; not to tell something (to anyone).  Don’t worry, I’ll keep your secret. I won’t even open my mouth.  Have no fear. I won’t utter a word.
not adequate.  Sorry, your paper isn’t up to scratch. Please do it over again.  The performance was not up to snuff.
not adequate.  Sorry, your paper isn’t up to scratch. Please do it over again.  The performance was not up to snuff.
worthless.  This land is all swampy. It’s not worth a dime.  This pen I bought isn’t worth a dime. It has no ink.
